g.text: 23. Ban, M. et al. Solution-processed perovskite light emitting diodes with
efﬁciency exceeding 15% through additive-controlled nanostructure tailoring.
Nat. Commun.
24. Yang, X. et al. Efﬁcient green light-emitting diodes based on quasi-two-
dimensional composition and phase engineered perovskite with surface
passivation.
Nat. Commun.
25. Dohner, E. R., Jaffe, A., Bradshaw, L. R. & Karunadasa, H. I. Intrinsic white-
light emission from layered hybrid perovskites.
J. Am. Chem. Soc.
26. Li, G. et al. Highly efﬁcient perovskite nanocrystal light‐emitting diodes
enabled by a universal crosslinking method.
Adv. Mater.
27. Lin, Y. et al. Excess charge-carrier induced instability of hybrid perovskites.
Nat. Commun.
28. Slotcavage, D. J., Karunadasa, H. I. & McGehee, M. D. Light-induced phase
segregation in halide-perovskite absorbers.
ACS Energy Lett.
29. Li, W. et al. Phase segregation enhanced ion movement in efﬁcient inorganic
CsPbIBr2 solar cells.
Adv. Energy Mater.
30. Barker, A. J. et al. Defect-assisted photoinduced halide segregation in mixed-
halide perovskite thin ﬁlms.
ACS Energy Lett.
31. Yuan, Y. et al. Electric‐ﬁeld‐driven reversible conversion between
Methylammonium lead triiodide perovskites and lead iodide at elevated
temperatures.
Adv. Energy Mater.
32. Xing, J. et al. Ultrafast ion migration in hybrid perovskite polycrystalline thin
ﬁlms under light and suppression in single crystals.
Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys.
33. Mizusaki, J., Arai, K. & Fueki, K. Ionic conduction of the perovskite-type
halides.
Sol. State Ion.
34. Lin, Y. et al. Suppressed ion migration in low-dimensional perovskites.
ACS
Energy Lett.
35. Lin, Y. et al. Unveiling the operation mechanism of layered perovskite solar
cells.
Nat. Commun.
36. Ma, D. et al. Single-crystal microplates of two-dimensional organic–inorganic
lead halide layered perovskites for optoelectronics.
Nano Res.
37. Bhaumik, S. et al. Highly stable, luminescent core–shell type
methylammonium–octylammonium lead bromide layered perovskite
nanoparticles.
Chem. Commun.
38. Yuan, M. et al. Perovskite energy funnels for efﬁcient light-emitting diodes.
Nat. Nanotechnol.
39. Saidaminov, M. I. et al. High-quality bulk hybrid perovskite single crystals
within minutes by inverse temperature crystallization.
Nat. Commun.
40. Dirin, D. N., Cherniukh, I., Yakunin, S., Shynkarenko, Y. & Kovalenko, M. V.
Solution-Grown CsPbBr3 Perovskite single crystals for photon detection.
Chem. Mater.
41. Gong, X. et al. Electron–phonon interaction in efﬁcient perovskite blue
emitters.
Nat. Mater.
42. Guo, Z., Wu, X., Zhu, T., Zhu, X. & Huang, L. Electron–phonon scattering in
atomically thin 2D perovskites.
ACS Nano
43. Wright, A. D. et al. Electron–phonon coupling in hybrid lead halide
perovskites.
Nat. Commun.
44. de Mello, J. C., Wittmann, H. F. & Friend, R. H. An improved experimental
determination of external photoluminescence quantum efﬁciency.
Adv. Mater.
45. Kresse, G. & Furthmüller, J. Efﬁcient iterative schemes for ab initio total-
energy calculations using a plane-wave basis set.
Phys. Rev. B
46. Kresse, G. & Furthmüller, J. Efﬁciency of ab-initio total energy calculations for
metals and semiconductors using a plane-wave basis set.
Comput. Mater. Sci.
47. Blöchl, P. E. Projector augmented-wave method.
Phys. Rev. B
48. Perdew, J. P., Burke, K. & Ernzerhof, M. Generalized gradient approximation
made simple.
Phys. Rev. Lett.
Acknowledgements
We acknowledge support for the device work from National Science Foundation under
award DMR-1903981. We acknowledge support for the mechanism study including
computation from the Center for Hybrid Organic Inorganic Semiconductors for Energy
(CHOISE), an Energy Frontier Research Center funded by the DOE Ofﬁce of Basic
Energy Sciences, Ofﬁce of Science. A.M. acknowledges support for the transient
absorption characterizations from the National Science Foundation grant CHE-1763207
Author contributions
J.H. and Q.W. conceived the idea. Q.W. fabricated the devices and performed the device-
efﬁciency measurement. Z.Y. conducted photoluminescence quantum yield measure-
ment. N.Z. and A.M. conducted transient absorption measurement. J.Z., Y.D., and X.X.
conducted X-ray diffraction measurement. P.R. conducted ICP measurement. X.W. and
Y.Y. conducted the simulation. Q.W. and J.H. wrote the paper.
Competing interests
The authors declare no competing interests.

is available for this paper at
Correspondence
and requests for materials should be addressed to J.H.

thanks the anonymous reviewer(s) for
their contribution to the peer review of this work.
